Rafting "N" Teams

Rafting is an exhilarating outdoor adventure activity that involves navigating a river, often through "whitewater" rapids, using a durable inflatable raft and paddles. It is a popular team sport that requires coordination, communication, and, most importantly, teamwork among a group of 4 to 12 people to successfully navigate the water. While it can be an extreme sport on dangerous rivers, it is also highly accessible for beginners, families, and tourists, with many guided, safe, and commercialized options available worldwide.

History

Rafting began as ancient river transport, evolving with the invention of the rubber raft by John Fremont in the 1840s, leading to the first commercial trips in the 1940s on rivers like the Snake. It gained popularity as a recreational sport in the 1950s-70s, becoming a mainstream adventure with modern synthetic rafts and safety equipment, eventually appearing in the 1972 Olympics.
